articles.title: Document Filing Information
articles.summary: This document consists of the Articles of Incorporation for the San Jose Amateur Astronomers, filed with the California Secretary of State on August 26, 1955. It establishes the organization as a non-profit corporation dedicated to promoting astronomy and meteorology through group study, technology sharing, and educational, scientific, and philanthropic pursuits. The articles outline the corporation's perpetual existence, its principal office in Santa Clara County, and list the initial seven directors.

articles.title: Introduction and Preamble
articles.summary: This document outlines the Articles of Incorporation for the San Jose Amateur Astronomers, a non-profit corporation formed in California on August 16, 1955. Its primary purpose is to promote the study of astronomy and meteorology through group participation, shared technology, and educational, scientific, and charitable pursuits. The articles detail the corporation's perpetual existence, its principal office in Santa Clara County, the initial board of seven directors, and its non-pecuniary nature.

articles.title: Article II: Primary Purpose
articles.summary: This document details the Articles of Incorporation for a non-profit corporation established in 1955 in Santa Clara County, California. Its primary purpose is to advance astronomy through group study, participation, and sharing technology for instrument building, operating for educational, scientific, charitable, social, and recreational pursuits. The corporation, intended for perpetual existence, explicitly states it does not aim for pecuniary gain for its members.

articles.title: Article IV: Non-Profit Status
articles.summary: This document, Article IV, outlines the non-profit status of a corporation. It explicitly states that the organization does not seek financial gain or profit for its members. Instead, its primary objectives are defined as charitable, social, educational, and recreational purposes.

articles.title: Article VI: Principal Office Location
articles.summary: This article, part of a corporation's foundational documents, specifies that the principal office for transacting business will be located in Santa Clara County, California. The corporation's existence is intended to be perpetual.

articles.title: Article VII: Number of Directors
articles.summary: This article establishes that the corporation will have seven directors. The number of directors can be modified either by an amendment to the Articles of Incorporation or by a by-law formally adopted by the corporation's members.

articles.title: Article VIII: Initial Directors
articles.summary: This document, dated August 16, 1955, outlines foundational elements for a new corporation. It lists the names and California addresses of the seven initial directors, who are tasked with adopting the corporation's by-laws. The document also specifies that details regarding membership qualifications, voting rights, and dues will be defined in these by-laws, and confirms that the corporation will not have capital stock. The instrument concludes with a notarized acknowledgment of the directors' signatures.

articles.title: Article X: By-Laws Adoption and Amendment
articles.summary: This article details the process for the adoption and amendment of a corporation's by-laws. It specifies that initial by-laws are adopted by the directors named in the Articles of Incorporation. Subsequent amendments or repeals can be made through methods outlined in the by-laws themselves or by legal provisions, with the by-laws also defining financial aspects like dues and assessments.

articles.title: Article XI: No Capital Stock
articles.summary: Article XI of the document explicitly states that the corporation in question shall not possess capital stock. This indicates a corporate structure that deviates from typical for-profit entities, likely signifying a non-stock or non-profit organization.

articles.title: Witness Clause and Signatures
articles.summary: This document excerpt presents the concluding witness clause and a list of signatures from a corporate filing dated August 16, 1955. It states that the corporation shall not have capital stock and lists seven individuals who affixed their signatures.

articles.title: Notary Public Acknowledgment
articles.summary: This document is a Notary Public Acknowledgment from August 16, 1955, issued in Santa Clara County, California. Notary Public H. G. Hill certified that several named individuals personally appeared before him and acknowledged their execution of a preceding instrument. It serves as official verification that the listed individuals signed and confirmed the document in the notary's presence.
